title: Fix Gong MCP client for cache auto-backfill in UI context
notes:
## Solution Implemented

Changed Gong MCP wrapper to use **Amp SDK routing exclusively** (Option C: Hybrid Approach).

### Root Cause
Direct StdioClientTransport MCP client hangs when called outside Amp's execution context. The subprocess expects MCP protocol handshakes that only work when Amp manages the lifecycle.

### Fix Applied
Modified \`src/phases/ingest/mcp-wrapper.ts\`:
- All \`callGong*\` functions now use \`globalThis\` functions only
- Removed try/catch with direct MCP client fallback
- Gracefully returns empty data when not in Amp context

### Workflow
1. **Initial backfill**: Must be done from Amp thread (use this tool)
2. **Subsequent queries**: Cache serves data (fast, no MCP calls)
3. **Incremental sync**: Also requires Amp context to fetch new calls

### Files Changed
- \`src/phases/ingest/mcp-wrapper.ts\` - Gong wrapper functions
- \`src/gong-cache/manager.ts\` - Added documentation
- \`scripts/backfill-gong-cache.md\` - How-to guide

### Trade-offs
- ✅ Works reliably in Amp context
- ✅ No hanging subprocesses
- ✅ Cache serves 99% of queries (no LLM cost)
- ❌ Cannot backfill from standalone scripts
- ❌ Requires Amp thread for initial setup

### Testing
Auto-backfill attempt from web UI now fails gracefully with warning instead of hanging.

title: Refactor data refresh to use Amp agent context for MCP access
notes:
Design and implement proper MCP-aware data refresh architecture.

CURRENT PROBLEMS:
- Refresh scripts call ingest functions directly via 'npx tsx'
- npx tsx context has no MCP servers loaded
- MCPs only available in Amp agent SDK context
- Workarounds are confusing (some buttons work, others don't)

PROPOSED SOLUTION:
Create lightweight agent wrappers that:
1. Run in Amp context (via amp-agent-sdk)
2. Call existing ingest phase functions
3. Stream progress via SSE
4. Work for both individual source refresh AND full refresh

ARCHITECTURE OPTIONS:

A) Hybrid: Keep existing ingest functions, wrap in Amp execute()
   - scripts/refresh-salesforce.ts uses execute() with prompt to call ingest
   - Prompt instructs agent to use MCP tools and call our functions
   - Pros: Reuses all existing code
   - Cons: Adds LLM latency, token cost

B) Direct MCP wrapping: Make ingest functions Amp-aware
   - Detect if running in Amp context vs standalone
   - If standalone, show helpful error
   - If in Amp, use MCPs directly
   - Pros: No LLM overhead, clean separation
   - Cons: Requires refactoring ingest functions

C) Unified refresh agent: Single agent handles all refresh types
   - One script that takes source param (salesforce/gong/notion/all)
   - Uses orchestrator phases but skips consolidation/draft/sync
   - Pros: Simplest, most maintainable
   - Cons: Less granular control

RECOMMENDATION: Option C
- Create src/agents/refreshData.ts
- Takes accountKey + options: {sources: ['salesforce'|'gong'|'notion'|'all'], mode: 'auto'|'full'}
- Reuses existing orchestrator phases (intake, research, enrich)
- api-server.ts spawns this ONE agent for all refresh operations

FILES TO CREATE/MODIFY:
- src/agents/refreshData.ts (new unified refresh agent)
- api-server.ts (update refresh endpoint to use refreshData agent)
- web/components/DataSourceBadges.tsx (already has SSE streaming)

ACCEPTANCE CRITERIA:
- All data source refresh buttons work
- Full Refresh button works
- Progress streaming shows real updates
- Works without external MCP configuration
- No duplicate code between refresh types
